quote: It's funny... before yesterday,    I'd never set foot on this    station -- but it's as familiar    to me as the back of my hand.
Isn't that odd?
You have no idea who I am, do    you?
I didn't think so.       Thanks for listening anyway..
I was killed here.
I mean, Jadzia was.
I try not to think about that.    If I did, I'm not sure I could    come here.
(looking down at the    spot)   It's a strange sensation. Dying.   No matter how many times it   happens to you, you never get   used to it.
It must be a little disconcerting    for you -- knowing that I have    Jadzia's memories.
No wonder you're uncomfortable.
It's a lot to get used to...
Tell me about it.
Well... I'll let you get to your   prayers...
How's my favorite Ferengi?
That depends which Ferengi you're   talking about.
I'm talking about you, Quark.    Who else would I be talking    about?
Dax.
Hi.
I was wondering when you were    going to drop by.
I can't believe it's really you.
Me, neither.    (off Quark's    confused    expression)   I mean... of course I can believe   I'm really "me" as in Ezri. It's   just I haven't gotten used to the   idea of "me" as in Dax.
Well, whoever you are, let me buy    you a drink.
(unsure if she likes     it)    Bloodwine...
That's the good stuff -- same    vintage I served when you and    Worf got married.
Smells awful...
It used to be your favorite.
(handing over the     glass with her     right hand)    I used to be left-handed, too. A    lot of things have changed since    I was joined.
I can imagine. Seven lifetimes    worth of memories would mix    anybody up.       Or is it eight?
Who knows anymore?
(giving her    something else to    drink)   It'll be easier once you get   settled in. Have you picked out   your quarters yet?
I'm not staying. I'm going back    to the Destiny to be assistant   ship's counselor.
You're a therapist?
Why does everyone sound so    surprised when they hear that?
It's just...        You're so young.
Why are you in such a hurry to    leave, anyway? Why not stay for    a while, get to know your old    friends again.
I don't want to force things.    People need time to get over    losing Jadzia.
I started getting over her the    minute you walked in. No    offense.
None taken.        I think.
You know something, Quark.    Besides Benjamin, you're the only    one of Jadzia's friends who    doesn't seem uncomfortable around    me.
She and I were close, I don't see    any reason why we shouldn't be    close, too.
Remember all those late night    tongo games?
Who could forget?        Wait a minute... you owe me ten    slips of latinum from our last    game.
I don't think so.
I won with a Full Consortium. I    remember.
Your memory must be playing    tricks on you.
Don't say that, Quark. I'm    confused enough as it is.
Look who's here!
I bet you two have a lot to talk    about.
Maybe not...
Come in.
Dax...
Are you alone?
Why are you sneaking in this way?
I didn't want to go through Ops,   in case Worf was there.
We bumped into each other last   night in Quark's.
It didn't go well, I take it?
You weren't expecting him to    accept you right away, were you?
Of course not. But he wouldn't    even talk to me.
Maybe he's just trying to respect    your customs -- he knows that    joined Trill aren't supposed to    get involved with the people    their previous hosts were married    to.
That doesn't mean we can't talk   to each other. Worf knows that.
Are you sure?
I told him all about Trill    traditions -- Jadzia did. We    discussed them.    (frustrated with the    pronoun confusion)   They discussed them.
I understand.
These pronouns are driving me    crazy.
Look at him, Benjamin. He's in    pain.
How can you tell?
I was his wife. I can tell.
I don't want to put him through    any more heartache than he's    already going through. It's a    good thing I'm going back to the    Destiny.
(wishing it weren't     true)    So you're still planning on    leaving?
I can't stay. I couldn't do that    to him. Besides, I think it    might be easier for me on the    Destiny. There are too many    memories here...
I'm going to miss you, old man.
I'm going to miss you too,   Benjamin.
-- no, I'm going to be Travis.   You're Crockett.
And who am I going to be again?
General Santa Anna.       When can our costumes be ready?
Garak?
Hmm?
Our holosuite costumes -- when   can they be ready?
I'm afraid you're going to have   to get them from somewhere else.
My shop's closed.
Still?
Starfleet Intelligence is keeping    me quite busy these days.
What if we let you be Crockett?
Hey.

Even if I was interested, I don't    have the time. Do you have any    idea how long it takes to decode    a Cardassian military    transmission? I invented some of    the basic encryption protocols    when I was with the Obsidian    Order, and it still takes me days    to decipher a simple sentence.
You've got to take a break sometime.
I intend to. As soon as the    Dominion has been driven off    Cardassia.
(turning suddenly to     the people behind     him)   Must you stand so close?
That was a little harsh.
I don't like people looming over   me.       I have to get back to work.       Thank you for your company,   gentlemen.
Starfleet intercepted another   Cardassian military transmission.
Are you all right?
Garak!
Can't... breathe...
Odo to Infirmary -- we have a    medical emergency.
He had a claustrophobic attack in    his shop...
His shop?        I don't understand. That's a    good sized space.

I know.    (trying to make    sense of it)   I've been claustrophobic for as   long as I can remember, but   lately it seems to have gotten   worse. Rooms that I once found   completely tolerable suddenly   feel alarmingly cramped.
I wish I had an explanation, but    I don't. He checks out fine.
Well, I don't feel fine.
Would you gentlemen mind terribly   if we continued this conversation   on the Promenade?
Better?
A little.
Mister Garak, as much as I    sympathize with your situation,    I'm not sure why you asked to see    me.

I was hoping you'd be kind enough    to express my regrets to    Starfleet Intelligence. When I    get like this, my concentration    isn't what it should be. I'm    afraid I'm not going to be up to    decoding transmissions for a    while.
Can I let them know when you    might be back on the job?
I wish I could say.        Believe me, captain, I'm not    happy about it either. I want to    see this war end as much as you    do.
Now if you'll excuse me, I'm    going to go hem some pants.    (off their puzzled    looks)   For some reason, sewing seems to   calm me down.
Sewing?
We can't afford to lose Garak    right now. Is there anything you    can do for him?
To be blunt, our friend Garak    needs to have his head examined.
Me? You want me to work with    Garak?
You're a counselor, aren't you?
Assistant counselor. I'm still    in training.
Come on, Dax. What are you going    to learn in the next few months    that you haven't already learned    in the last three hundred years?
How to keep from breaking into    tears for no reason; how to    resist the urge to stand on my    head -- things like that.
Why are you standing on your    head?
Emony used to do it.
The gymnast?
She found it relaxing.
Do you?
Actually, it's giving me a    headache.
What about Julian, can't he work    with Garak?

Julian's a good physician, but    he's not a counselor --    (before she can     point it out)    -- or even an assistant   counselor. And besides, he    doesn't have eight lifetimes of    experience under his belt.
I bet he doesn't stand on his    head for no reason, either.
You can do this, old man. I know    you can.
All right. I'll try. I just    wish I had as much confidence in    me as you do.
So what do you think?
About what?
About her.
Who?
Dax.
Ezri? She seems... nice.
Meaning what?
Meaning... nice.
Come on, Doctor. I know the way   you felt about Jadzia.
She's not Jadzia.
She's the next best thing.       So are you interested?
Sounds to me like you're the one   who's interested.
It's not every day you get a   second chance with a woman.
She's not the same woman.
She's still Dax, isn't she?
More or less.
That's good enough for me.       Ready for a little competition?
You're insane.
And you... are going to lose.
Am I interrupting?
You must be Ezri Dax. The    captain told me you'd be dropping    by to... "counsel" me.
Is that all right?
That depends on what's involved.    You see, I'm a very private    person.
I understand. So is it helping?
The sewing. Is it making you    feel better?
Thankfully, yes. In fact --
(before he can     continue)    You're lucky, nothing helps me.
Are you claustrophobic, too?
What makes you say that?
You just said --
(realizing the     misunderstanding)    No, I get spacesick. Ever since    I was joined. I'm very sensitive    to motion. I can even feel the    station spinning.
Really?
It's because of what happened to    Torias. He died in a shuttle    accident.
Why would that make you    spacesick?
Because I blame myself for what    happened.
You were piloting?
Yes. No. Depends on how you    look at it. Torias was my fifth    host. Didn't I say that?
No.
Well, he was. And I think the    reason his death has stayed with    me for so long is that I just    can't seem to forgive him for    getting himself killed.
But you said it was an accident.    If he wasn't to blame, then    you're not to blame, either.
I know. But somehow I can't help    punishing myself for it.
By getting spacesick.
Exactly.
Don't take this the wrong way,    but it sounds to me like you're    the one that needs to see a    counselor.
You're probably right. But I    didn't come here to talk about my    problems.
Do you remember anything   traumatic happening to you when   you were young -- something that   involved getting trapped in a   confined space.
If I'd been that careless, my    father would've left me there to    teach me a lesson.
Sounds like he was strict.
He didn't get to be the head of    the Obsidian Order without a    sense of... discipline.
Did he discipline you?
He'd punish me when I misbehaved.    What father wouldn't?
Did your mother approve of his    punishments?
Not that it mattered. She didn't    have a key to the closet.
The closet?
My father used to lock me in when    I misbehaved.
(why didn't you tell    me?)   Garak, I asked you if you'd ever   been trapped in a confined space   when you were young.
I wasn't trapped. I knew he'd    let me out when I learned my    lesson.
Learned your lesson?
(tugging at his     collar)    I could be very stubborn.
That's not the point. Nothing a    child could do justifies locking    him in a closet.
No wonder you get claustrophobic.    It's just like me getting    spacesick. We're both punishing    ourselves for things that weren't    our fault.
Are you saying that if I can stop    blaming myself, my claustrophobia    will just disappear?
Not overnight, but letting go of    all this misplaced guilt would be    a good start.
(dabbing his     forehead)    Well, I'll certainly give your    advice some thought.
Are you all right?
To tell you the truth, I'm    starting to feel a little    claustrophobic.
Probably because we've been    talking about it.        Actually, I'm starting to feel a    little spacesick myself.
If you don't mind, I think I'll    get back to my sewing.
Good idea.
(picking up his     seamer)    Thank you for coming by.
My pleasure...
Hello, Worf.
Ensign.
Ensign? That's all you have to    say to me?
What more is there to say?
I was your wife.
You are not Jadzia. She died and    went to Sto-vo-kor. I do not    know you, nor do I wish to.
Come in.
Dax... ?
Do you think the chief could    adjust the inertial dampers so    the station would spin a little    slower?
I don't know. Why?
Never mind.        To what do I owe the pleasure?
I'm not going to say I told you    so, but Garak dropped by Odo's    office this morning. He wanted    to pick up the latest Cardassian    transmissions for decoding.
Really?
Looks like his claustrophobia is    under control.
I guess our talk must've    helped...
Told you so.
I thought you said you weren't    going to say that.
Couldn't resist.
You all right?
I talked with Worf.
How'd it go?
He doesn't want to have anything    to do with me.
Maybe I should have a talk with    him.
Absolutely not. You intimidate    him.
Me?
Don't tell him I told you.
(trying to get used     to the idea)    I intimidate Worf.
You like that, don't you?
Of course not.
Come on. I've been a man, I    know.

Look, we're not talking about me    and Worf, we're talking about you    and Worf. Now, I sympathize with    what he's going through, but as    far as I'm concerned, you have as    much right to be here as he does.
(sensing he's taking    this somewhere)   What are you getting at,   Benjamin?
This war hasn't been good for    morale around here. I've been    thinking the station could use a    counselor. I can't think of    anyone better suited for the job.
Thanks for saying that. But even    if Worf wasn't an issue, I'm    still just an assistant    counselor.
I took the liberty of contacting    Starfleet Medical. They're    willing to waive the rest of your    training and give you a    commission as a full counselor    with the rank of lieutenant.
How'd you talk them into that?
I asked them what they thought    you were going to learn in the    next few months --
That I haven't already learned in    the last three hundred years.
They saw my point. I wish you    would, too.
Benjamin, it means a lot to know    that you want me to stay. But I    can't.
Because of Worf...
Mostly.
Just say the word, and I'll go    intimidate him for you.
You'd like that, wouldn't you?
I'danian spice pudding. No,    cancel that. I'll have kilm    steak, rare. No, Tobin was a    vegetarian. Give me...
Two Fanalian toddys, hot.
How'd you know?
Lucky guess.
Join me?
Sure.
So... here we are.
What was that?
What was what?
That look.
(unsure if he should     tell her)   This might be the last thing you   want to hear right now... but you   have Jadzia's eyes.       I shouldn't have said anything.
Don't flirt with me, Julian.   Please.
I'm not.
I remember the way you used to   flirt with Jadzia.
It was just an observation.
Good. Because I'm not like her.   She knew how to handle it.    (come to think of     it)   In fact, she enjoyed it.
Really?
You didn't know?
Well, I suspected...
You can be very charming.    (knowing this will     mean a lot to him)   And you want to know something?   If Worf hadn't come along, it   would've been you...
You really miss her, don't you?
I suppose I always will... but    somehow, talking to you seems to    help.
Deputy Talpet to Doctor Bashir.
Go ahead.
We have a medical emergency in   Airlock Seven. It's Garak, sir.
On my way.
Open it! Let me out!
Breathe in...
And out.    (repeating the     process)    In... and out.        Better?
(trying to get him    to take in the    view)   Beautiful, isn't it? Look at   that sky. It just goes on and   on.
No, it doesn't. It's an    illusion. There's a holosuite    wall not ten meters in front of   us.
But you can't see it.
I can feel it.
We could call up another program.
I can't believe the way I    humiliated myself back there.    (trying to make     sense of what he     did)    I just wanted to... get out.    I couldn't breathe.
If you were looking for fresh    air, you were knocking on the    wrong door.

(trying to rally     himself)    I have to get this situation    under control. If I don't, I'm    going to be forced to leave the    station.        Where would I go? I can't go    back to Cardassia... I doubt I'd    be welcome on Bajor...
You're not going to have to leave    the station. I'll talk to Quark    and tell him to make this    holosuite available to you twenty-   six hours a day.
Whenever you feel like walking   out the nearest airlock, you can   come here instead.
It's going to be all right   we're going to get this under   control. I promise.
If you don't mind, I'd like to    sit here and be alone for a    while.
I'll check in on you later.
Ow!
Hold still.       I think I've got something.
I knew it. Never get a Tympanic   Tickle from an amateur.
Tympanic Tickle... ?    (before Quark can     explain)   Never mind. I don't want to   know.       Sit tight. I'm going to get you   an antibiotic.
We need to talk.
About what?
Do not toy with me, Doctor. I   know how you felt about Jadzia.
Worf, that was a long time ago.
I saw you with her.
With Jadzia?
You know who I'm talking about.
You've got it all wrong.
Stay away from her.
Now wait just a minute.
You have no right to tell me who   I can be friends with.
If you dishonor Jadzia's memory,   you will regret it.
That goes for you too, Ferengi.
What did I do... ?
Uh-oh.        Keep an eye out for Worf.
Hi, Quark. Can I have a cup of    coffee?
(trying to get rid of    her)   Why would you want to pay me for   coffee when you can get it for   free at the Replimat?
Ah.        Oh.
Can I have a cup of coffee,    please? I want to get back up to    Garak.
He's gone. He left about an hour    ago.
(surprised and     concerned)    Where'd he go?
I don't know.        Well, don't just stand there. Go    find him.
Garak... ?
I thought you were going to stay    in the holosuite for a while.

I got tired of looking at a fake    landscape and pretending I was    outside. Work is the answer.    My father always used to say that    a person should throw themselves    into their work.        Do your chores, Elim. I told you    to do your chores.
And if you didn't? What would he    do to you?

Oh, no. Don't start. Spare me    your insipid psychobabble. I'm    not some quivering neurotic who    feels sorry for himself because    his daddy wasn't nice to him.        You couldn't begin to understand    me.
I'd like to try.
I'm sure you would. You'd like    nothing more than to pry into my    personal affairs.

Well, I'm not interested in   dissecting my childhood... all I   want is to free my people from   the Dominion. I don't need   someone to come in here and hold   my hand, I need someone who can   help me get back to work. And   you, my dear, aren't up to the   task.

Look at you. You're pathetic.   A confused child trying to live   up to the legacy left by her   predecessors. You're not worthy   of the name Dax. I knew Jadzia --   she was vital -- alive. She   owned herself. But you -- you   don't even know who you are.       How dare you presume to help me?   You can't even help yourself.
Now, get out of here. Before I   say something unkind.
What's this all about?
What does it look like? I'm    resigning from Starfleet.
Why?
Because I can't do my job.    Garak's right -- how can I help    other people when I can't even    help myself?
I know this has been a hard time    for you, old man --
Don't call me that! I'm not the    old man. I'm not Curzon. Or    Jadzia.
No, you're Ezri. Ezri Dax.    You've been given eight lifetimes    worth of experience -- I know    it's confusing right now, but in    time you'll see it's a wonderful    gift.
It's a gift I don't deserve.
If that's the way you feel, then    go back to Trill. Talk to the    Symbiosis Commission -- maybe    you can convince them to take the    symbiont out of you.
I wish they could. But removing    the symbiont would kill me, you    know that.

If you're leaving Starfleet,    you're going to have to find    something to do. Maybe you could    be one of those people who takes    care of the symbiont pools? It's    quiet in those caves. No one    around, no one expecting great    things from you. You could spend    the rest of your life    underground, in the dark,    stirring mud. Eighty or ninety    years of that might be just what    you need.        And as for Dax? That symbiont's    had eight amazing lives -- so    what if the ninth is a waste?
Stop it, Benjamin. I thought you    of all people would understand--
I do understand. You were right.    You don't deserve the Dax    symbiont. And frankly, you don't    deserve to wear that uniform.
I'll pass this on to Starfleet    Command. Dismissed.
Yes.
Not again.
Compliments of Doctor Bashir.
He sent you here?
It was my idea.        Now, if you want to skip the    drinking and get right down to    talking, I'm game.
(getting back to his    bat'leth)   What do you wish to discuss?
Julian swears there's nothing    going on between him and Ezri.    There's no reason for you to be    jealous.
This has nothing to do with    jealousy. I know the Doctor    cared for Jadzia. But this woman    is not Jadzia. And treating her    as if she were dishonors her    memory.
No, treating Ezri like a stranger    dishonors Jadzia's memory.
It doesn't make sense. She is    not Jadzia, yet she is. How can    I honor the memory of the woman I    loved when she's not really dead?
I don't have an answer for you,    Worf. But let me ask you this:    how do you think Jadzia would've    wanted you to treat Ezri?
There is no way to know.
Yes, there is. And the person    who can tell you is the person    you've been avoiding ever since    she got here.
I didn't think you'd darken my    doorstep again.
I just wanted to say I'm sorry.    I wish I'd been able to help you.
So do I.
Well, don't worry. I won't be    bothering you anymore. I'm    leaving in the morning.
Yes, I heard the Destiny was    going to be arriving tomorrow.
They're putting in for supplies    before they head to the front.    But I won't be going with them.    I've decided to go back to Trill.
How nice for you.
(thinking he might    be interested)   Actually, the Destiny's going to   join the Seventh Fleet at   Kalandra.
Kalandra?
Those transmissions you decoded    last week must've convinced    Starfleet that it's a good place    to launch a new offensive.
Yes... the transmissions did    indicate it was somewhat    vulnerable.
If the offensive goes well,    Starfleet will have you to thank    for it.
(tugging at his     collar)    That's very gratifying...
I just thought you should know...
Are you all right?
Of course I'm all right. That's    very good news about Kalandra.
Let's just hope it goes well.    The Cardassians will put up a    strong fight.
Indeed they will. But in the    end, they'll lose.
How can you be so sure?
Because they won't be expecting    an attack.        They have no idea I broke their    code.
All those Cardassians are going    to die... because of me...
I suppose that's one way to look    at it.
What other way is there?
That by helping to end the war,    you're saving lives.
Who will I be saving -- Humans,    Klingons, Romulans?
And Cardassians.
No, not Cardassians. They're    going to fight to the end. The    Dominion will see to that.

Don't you see? I wanted to    believe I was helping my people,    liberating them, but all I've    done is pave the way for their    annihilation. I'm a traitor!   I've betrayed --        -- every...        -- thing...
Dax to Infirmary, I need a    medical team.
How are you feeling?
Well... I'm breathing a lot    better than I was.
At least we found out what's been    triggering these claustrophobic    attacks you've been having.

(trying to make    sense of it)   When I first agreed to help   Starfleet, I was convinced that   it was the right thing to do. I   didn't allow myself to doubt it,   even for a moment. I never   realized how much it was gnawing   away at me.        I suppose I was looking for a way    out... and the claustrophobia    gave me an excuse to stop    fighting against my people.
Now that you know that, what are    you going to do?
Get back to work. What else can    I do? The Dominion has to be    stopped. Even if it means the    destruction of Cardassia.
The captain's going to be glad to    hear you're back on the job.
He has you to thank for it.        And so do I.
So what about you? Are you still    planning on going back to Trill?
No. I'm going to stay in    Starfleet.
I'm sure the captain will be glad    to hear that, too.
My resignation --
(re: the PADD in his     hand)    Now what?
It's my request to be reinstated    into Starfleet.
I can't send this to Starfleet    Command.
Why not?
Because I never sent in your    resignation.
I had a feeling you didn't mean    all those things you said to me.    You were just trying to rattle my    cage.
You've done it to me often    enough. I'm glad it worked.
Garak's asked that the latest    Cardassian transmissions be sent    to the Infirmary.        Well done.
Thanks.       Somehow I thought you'd be   happier to hear I'm staying in   Starfleet.
I guess I'd be happier if you   were staying here at D.S. Nine.
Me, too.       But you know I can't.
I hope Captain Raymer knows how    lucky she is. She's getting a    hell of a counselor.
Yes.
May I come in?
Of course.
I understand that you are leaving    in the morning.
That's right.
I am not certain that I have    treated you the way Jadzia    would've wanted me to.
You'll get no argument from me    there.
I loved her with all my heart.
And she loved you...
Part of me is glad to know that    she is not gone forever... but    even so, in some ways it would be    easier if she were.
I know.
I have heard that the captain has    offered you a position as station    counselor.        I would not want you to decline    on my account.
Worf, I can't stay. I couldn't    do that to you.
Do you wish to stay?
Very much.
Then do. Jadzia would not have    wanted you to leave because of me.
Thank you.
It will be a long time before I    can accept that I have lost her.    Until then...
You need some breathing room. I    understand.
Congratulations, lieutenant.
I want you to take a good look    around.        Because you've just agreed to    take responsibility for the    mental health of everyone in this    room.
You've got your work cut out for   you.
It's a good thing they made you a   lieutenant. I can't see taking   advice from an ensign.
Since when do you take advice   from anyone?
Why don't you join us for dinner    tonight?
I don't want to put you out.
Please come. It'll take the    pressure off me. He just sits    there and counts how many times I    chew.
I'll be there.
She is cute.
She's also about three hundred    years too old for you.
I took the liberty of putting    together a plate for you.
Thanks, Quark.        Worf's not here, is he?
Good question.
Congratulations, quite a crowd.
I hope it's not making you    uncomfortable.
Not at all.
I need you to explain something    to someone.
Morn, it's me. Dax.
